citation.article-title: Aeromonas schubertii, a new mannitol-negative species found in human clinical specimens.

p.s: Description of Aeromonas schubertii sp. nov.

Aeromonas schubertii (pronounced shu-bert'-ee-eye) is derived from the surname of Ralph H. W. Schubert, a German microbiologist who has contributed greatly to our knowledge of the genera Aeromonas and Plesiomonas(10-13). The species name is treated as a modern (neo) Latin genitive noun meaning "of Schubert."
The type strain of the species is designated CDC 2446-81 (ATCC 43700).
A complete description of A. schubertii is given to Tables 2 to 4.
The complete biochemical reactions of A. schubertii are given in Table 2.

The features of A. schubertii that differentiate it from other Aeromonas strains are its failure to ferment D-mannitol, sucrose, L-arabinose, or salicin, failure to produce indole, and failure to hydrolyze esculin (Table 5).
None of the strains produced gas from glucose.

The carbohydrate fermentation pattern we obtained was the same as that of Vibrio damsela, which is also lysine+, arginine+, and VP+. V. damsela, however, requires NaCl for growth (100%), is sensitive to the vibriostatic compound 0/129 (90%), and is string test positive (80%).

A. schubertii fits the description of the genus Aeromonas because it is fermentative, oxidase+, resistant to 0/129, and string test negative; does not require NaCl for growth; does not grow in 6% NaCl; ferments maltose; and reduces nitrate to nitrite. A. schubertii had an antibiogram typical of other Aeromonas strains: resistance to ampicillin, carbenicillin, and penicillin but susceptibility to chloramphenicol, colistin, gentamicin, and tetracycline (Table 4).
Practical identification of A. schubertii.

When the reactions ofthe type strain of A. schubertii were put into our computer program for identification of enteric organisms, it was called "Aeromonas hydrophila group-indole-, D-mannitol-, and sucrose-." Therefore, if an Aeromonas species is suspected, negative reactions for acid production in D-mannitol and sucrose would point to A. schubertii.

When the type strain, 2446-81, was compared biochemically with all other strains of Vibrionaceae and Enterobacteriaceae in our computer data base, the closest matches other than the remaining A. schubertii strains were three Aeromonas hydrophila strains, followed by one Vibrio cholerae strain.
Clinical significance of A. schubertii strains. A. schubertii strains were isolated from abscesses, wounds, skin, pleural fluid, and blood (Table 1).
They were isolated in southern coastal states and Puerto Rico.
The three strains that were isolated from blood and pleural fluid appear to have been from patients with underlying disease.
There have been no stool isolates.
The two blood isolates suggest clinical significance, and the sources of A. schubertii are quite typical for extraintestinal isolates of other Aeromonas species.
Perhaps this paper will stimulate others to report their experience with this organism.
Strain 2478-85.
Seven of the original eight isolates of Enteric Group 501 were highly related by DNA hybridization and phenotype.
However, strain 2478-85 was less related (70% at 60°C, 61% at 75°C, with a divergence of 5%).
This isolate was indole+ and lysine decarboxylase-.
These findings suggest that this strain is close to A. schubertii but has diverged somewhat.
For the present we have kept it in Enteric Group 501.
No clinical information is known about this strain.
The taxonomy of the A. hydrophila group, which has been discussed in previous papers (7, 9), remains unclear.
The DNA hybridization groups first described by Popoff et al. (9) and then confirmed at the Centers for Disease Control (7) still cannot all be differentiated phenotypically.
We recently described a distinct group of ornithine+ strains, A. veronii (7), which can be recognized biochemically.
However, we have also found an arginine+ group of strains (DNA group) that is highly related to A. veronii (7).
The new species that we describe in this paper, A. schubertii, can be distinguished phenotypically and by DNA relatedness from all other Aeromonas DNA hybridization groups.
We hope that by describing this new species, we can eliminate at least one group from the taxonomic confusion.
The problems of the other DNA hybridization groups will be addressed in a future publication.
